At that time, the BrahmÄ Heaven Holder of the Mind said to the bodhisattva Universal Practice:
Son of a great clan!

He replied:
The practices are all non-existent, yet they follow the practices of attachment of sentient beings.
He further asked:
If the practices of all sentient beings are practices of attachment, what are the practices of sentient beings?
He replied:
They arise from the practices of the TathÄgatas.
He further asked:
What are the practices of the TathÄgatas that are taken as practice?
He replied:
They take the practice of complete emptiness.
He further asked:
Do all the practices of foolish ordinary beings and the practices of the TathÄgata also accord with this?
If so, what is called the realm of the TathÄgata?
He replied:
Do you wish to make emptiness different?
He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
He replied:
How is it?
Didn't the World-Honored One say that all dharmas are empty?
He replied:
So it is.
He replied:
For this reason, all dharmas are without distinction.
Moreover, this practice is without characteristics.
Brahma Heaven should know that the TathÄgata does not dwell in the dharmas as being various.
Then Brahma Heaven Holder of the Mind asked Universally Good:
What is called practice, what is the practice?
He replied:
Practicing the four brahma practices is called practice.
He further asked Brahma Heaven:

Those who practice the four divine abodes do not practice emptiness. Wherever they practice, they always cultivate the four divine abodes, and only when they are fully endowed with all practices do they practice emptiness.
If, Brahma Heaven!
One practices in a secluded place or in the wilderness, and always fully possesses the four divine abodes, this is called practicing emptiness.

Even if one is in a lecture hall or pavilion, on a purple gold bed with multiple layers of bedding, but does not follow and cultivate the four divine abodes, this is not called practicing emptiness, because one does not understand the attainment of practice.
He also asked:
What kind of practice is the practice of wisdom and insight?
He replied:
If a practitioner does not see the body in emptiness.
He also asked:
If one does not see the self, does one see wisdom?
He replied:
Yes, Brahma Heaven!
One who does not see the self sees wisdom.
It is like, Brahma Heaven!
There are wise kings, or sagely emperors, whose ministers and officials possess wisdom and are respected by the emperor.
It is so, it is so, those who do not see me see pure wisdom.
He asked again:
Who does not see me?
He replied:
Those who have no self-nature possess a complete body, and such a class is called seeing the self.
He asked again:
According to what you have said, I observe that those who do not see the self see the Buddha.
Why is it so?
The self is naturally so, and the Buddha is also naturally so.
PÅ«rá¹‡a!ğŸ”½
What does the Tathagata see?
He replied:
Apart from seeing the self.
Why is it so?
Those who do not see the self see the Dharma, and those who see the Dharma see the Buddha.
He asked Pué¦– again:
If the causes and conditions of non-self are accomplished, then one attains equality?
He replied:
Brahma Heaven!
If one accomplishes all conditioned things, can one be said to attain equality?
He further asked:
How is it?
Virtuous One!
What is attained to achieve equality and accomplishment?
He replied:
Without eliminating anything and not realizing anything, one who practices this attains equality.
He further asked:
What does the eye of wisdom see?
He replied:
Brahma Heaven!
The eye of wisdom does not see anything. The eye of wisdom does not see conditioned or unconditioned things.
Why is it so?
Conceptual thoughts are conditioned, while the absence of conceptual thoughts is the eye of wisdom.
Those who illuminate and understand have already transcended all traces of the eye. For this reason, there is nothing to see.
He further asked Virtuous One:
If one attains equality through causes and conditions and self, will a bhiká¹£u thereby not attain the fruit?
He replied:
BrahmÄ!
Can one who has no equality attain the fruit of realization?
If one is not treated equally, even if one practices correctly, one will not attain the fruit of realization. Only by being free from conceptual thoughts can one see attainment.
If one abides in arrogance, which is not equal treatment, whether one is arrogant or not arrogant, one cannot be bound by time.
He further asked:
Puá¹£ya!
By what dharmas is one bound by time and said to be bound by time?
He replied:
Those dharmas that are unborn, that are not born now, and that will not be born in the future - that is the binding of time by all dharmas. I say that binding by time refers to this.
He further asked Puá¹£ya:
In this way, what is birth bound by time?
He replied:
In this way, in terms of time, that which is unborn is called birth. Transcending all views of conditioned phenomena, this is called equality.
He further asked:
What is meant by equality?
He replied:
Equality means the self and nirvana are not two, this is called equality;
Equality means not relying on anything, this is called equality;
Equanimity is called equality;
Without benefit or lack of benefit, right or wrong, this is called equality;
Eliminating all thoughts, this is called equality.
At that time, the World-Honored One praised Samantabhadra:
Excellent!
Excellent!
You have spoken these words well, just as it is said.

When this was spoken, seven thousand bhiká¹£us ended their outflows and their minds were liberated, twenty-two thousand devas were far from defilements, their minds were liberated from defilements, and attained the purity of the Dharma eye, ten thousand bhiká¹£us were free from desire, two hundred devas and humans gave rise to the intention of unsurpassed, true, and proper awakening, and five hundred bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
Then, the BrahmÄ Heaven's Son Who Upholds the Mind addressed the World-Honored One, saying:
Is the youth Puá¹£ya performing the Buddha's work?
Puá¹£ya then replied to the BrahmÄ Heaven's Son, saying:
The Buddha does not appear in the world to make the Dharma.
If one does not make the Dharma, is there a place to abide?
He further asked Puá¹£ya:
Hasn't the World-Honored One transformed countless people to attain nirvÄá¹‡a?
Haven't you benefited countless sentient beings?
He replied:
BrahmÄ Heaven's Son!
Is there anyone who wants to make what does not exist exist?
He replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
He replied:
Brahma Heaven!
Do you want to make the category of human beings achieve human form?
Replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
Answered:
Brahma Heaven!
Do you want to make the Tathagata unobstructed, or if nonexistent, to make it arise?
Replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
Answered:
What kind of human beings?
Are those whom the Tathagata saves able to attain nirvana?
Replied:
Purna!
The Dharma is unborn, as I explained before, in this way there is no birth and death, no nirvana, and nothing to attain.
Answered:
So it is, Brahma Heaven!
The Tathagata, the Perfectly Enlightened One, does not attain birth and death, nor does he attain nirvana.
Moreover, Brahma Heaven!
The liberated Shravakas transformed by the World-Honored One, if one considers them, they also have no birth and death, no nirvana, and yet they are in nirvana.
That is to say, Brahma Heaven!
Nirvana is just a worldly expression, a provisional name.
What is called birth and death is also a worldly expression, without beginning or end, and there is no nirvana.
He replied:
Samantabhadra!
Who would be willing to believe these words?
He answered:
Those who are not attached to any dharmas.
He further asked Samantabhadra:
What is attachment to?
He replied:
Brahma Heaven!
Attachment is attachment to falsehood.
If, Brahma Heaven!
Those who are sincere do not have arrogance towards this, nor do they have any pleasure, let alone be attached to emptiness.

Therefore, those who see sincerity are not attached, and being unattached, there is no birth and death. Having no birth and death, they do not depart from birth and death. Not departing from birth and death, this is called nirvana.
He also asked Boshi:
For those who attain nirvana, what do they aspire to in attaining nirvana?
He replied:
Brahma Heaven!

Those who attain nirvana are called those who turn to each other for causes, for the practice of their wisdom, the practice of all dharmas is tranquil and has no basis, and therefore has no abode. That which has no abode is called attaining nirvana;
The practice of having no abode is called eternal cessation, this is the expedient of the Way, and there is no birth, this is called the Four Noble Truths.
Then, the Bodhisattva Universal Practice asked Boshi:
What is being said now are all sincere and truthful words.
He replied:
Son of a good family!
All that is said is sincere and true.
He also asked Boshi:
Are the words that are false and deceptive echoes also sincere and true?
He replied:
They are truly sincere and true.
Why is it so?
What they say is all without location and without establishment. Having attained mastery, it is called true and real. All these words are all true and real.
The TathÄgata, the Worthy One, also speaks the teachings for the heavenly beings and humans. Considering these various words, they are also not various and not different.
Why is it so?

All that is said are the words of the TathÄgata. All the TathÄgatas also do not act, and do not advance or retreat. Those who have words or further expound the teachings are all like this. The teachings are the teachings.

For this reason, all that is said is equal in written characters. By means of equal written characters, one can then equally be one with written characters. Having already been able to be equal with all written characters, one attains mastery and can then be equal. All words and phrases universally practice equality.
He further asked Puá¹£ya:
Does the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, not distinguish between the words of the sages and the words of the non-sages?
He replied:ğŸ”½The TathÄgata, the Worthy One, does not distinguish between the words of the sages and the words of the non-sages. Why is it so?
Do you want the assembly of sages and saints to be a written teaching?
Do you also want there to be a sage and saintly teaching without written words?
He replied:
It is like this.
Boshu replied:
Do the sages and saints have thoughts about the written words of the sages and saints, or the absence of written words of the sages and saints?
He replied:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
He replied:
Therefore, written words have no thoughts. If one abandons all thoughts, this is called the sage and saintly teaching without words. The sages and saints do not speak using written words.

There are no thoughts of people or dharmas. It is like music and large drums, the sound arises from conditions but also has no thoughts. The sages and saints are also like this. They manifest speech and have words but are also unattached.
He also asked Boshu:
The TathÄgata said:
'When gathering, one should engage in two things: either discussing the Dharma, or like the sages, remaining in silent meditation.'
Puá¹£ya, what is meant by discussing the Dharma?
What is meant by the sages' silence?
He replied:
If one does not dispute the Buddha, does not go against the scriptures and Dharma, and does not disturb the noble assembly, this is called discussing the Dharma;
If one contemplates the Dharma, then one's mind is free from desires for form. The so-called Dharma is unconditioned and formless, and the so-called noble assembly is the sages' silence.
Furthermore, son of noble family!
If one diligently cultivates and discerns the four bases of mindfulness, this is called discussing the Dharma;
If the mind has no thoughts towards any phenomena, this is called the sages' silence.
Son of noble family!
If one diligently discerns and explains the four right efforts, this is called discussing the Dharma;
Speaking of the Dharma and equality means not grasping at equality or creating anything, which is called holy silence.
If one cultivates and expounds on the four bases of supernatural powers, that is called discussing the Dharma;
If there is no body, no speech, and no mind, that is called holy silence.
Cultivating and explaining the five faculties and five powers is called discussing the Dharma;

If there is no sound, one does not believe in the Dharma. There are no sages who select and grasp at dharmas. Single-mindedly establishing oneself, equally attaining liberation, and believing in all dharmas, thoroughly understanding all that is said and practicing wisdom, this is called the liberation of the sages.
Following the liberation of the sages in the seven factors of enlightenment is called discussing the Dharma;
Equally observing desire for form without elevating or demeaning, attaining this practice is called holy silence.
Cultivating and diligently explaining the eightfold noble path is called discussing the Dharma;
Having already seen the place of birth of the lineage, it is like a raft, not attached to the Dharma, not attached to non-Dharma, then it is called the holy silence.
Son of noble family, know that if one understands the return of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, this is called expounding the Dharma;

If one realizes the Dharma with the body, then one is not apart from the body, and seeing the Dharma is not apart from the Dharma. One who sees has no original seeing. If one does not see two, then one does not see two. As one sees, what is seen by present wisdom is not seen. One who does not see is called the holy silence.
Moreover, son of noble family!
Discriminating and explaining that it is not the same as self, not the same as others, not the same as the Dharma, this is expounding the Dharma;

Even if one does not attain the Dharma and is apart from the teachings of all written words, sounds, and speech, abandoning arrogance and giving rise to tranquility, with a mind of quiescence and ultimate in practice, this is called the tranquility of the sages.
Moreover, son of noble family!
If other sentient beings and different people each see these faculties and explain them separately;
If the mind is in concentration or if it is in chaos, these sages are in tranquility, with something established and without confusion.
Then, the Bodhisattva Universal Practice asked Universal Excellence:
As you now discuss, I observe that all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas return to principle, without the Dharma to speak and without the tranquility of sages.

Who will speak of their impartial mind?

It should be said that the TathÄgata is impartial, and only the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, can understand the fundamental nature of sentient beings and always abide in concentration.

If Pundarika Tathagata expounded the teachings of the Three Vehicles, and lectured on the sutras and Dharma for the Å›rÄvakas, and extensively explained the principles with added intention, then he would give rise to two practices and proclaim the Dharma and the practice of holy tranquility.

The Buddha's world is called Pure Universal Explanation SamÄdhi, and the world is named Pure because of one thing.
If a bodhisattva attains this samÄdhi, he abandons all conceptual defilements and attains the light of the Buddha's teachings, and therefore the world is called Pure.
Past dharmas are all pure, future dharmas are also all pure, and present dharmas are also all pure, this is called the two purities.
The reason it is called pure is that it is truly pure. That which is truly pure is also unborn and also pure.
That which is pure is originally pure, and therefore it is called originally pure. That which is originally pure is all dharmas.
What dharmas are originally pure?
Emptiness is originally pure, and then all are far removed.
All dharmas are all false, and the original purity of no-thought.
Moreover, all dharmas are thus to eliminate all thoughts and ideas, and the affairs of wrong thoughts are all extinguished. That which is wishless is originally pure.

All dharmas are not to be practiced, and that which is wishless is capable of ultimate completion. By being apart from spontaneity, one is able to be originally pure. This is called the original purity that manifests the radiance of original purity.
Just as birth and death are pure, so is nirvana originally pure;
just as nirvana is pure, so are all dharmas originally pure;
this is called original purity.
The manifestation of the mind is like, son of a great clan!

Space has no place and no aspirations. If one is able to heal afflictions with a single thought, the originally pure mind has no place and no aspirations, and is then able to remove the desires of afflictions.

This son of a good family, his mind is originally pure and his mind is manifested, just like the sky is not harmed by clouds, fog, or dust, and it is also neither destroyed nor illuminated. The sky is originally pure and cannot be defiled by anything, and because it is ultimately pure and never defiled, it is called the sky.

If one contemplates in accordance with what is appropriate, then the foolish words and thoughts of ordinary beings give rise to afflictions, but the mind's original purity cannot be defiled. Because it cannot be defiled, it is called originally pure. Therefore, liberation is called liberation.
This son of a good family!
The pure world universally enters into equality.
At that time, the World-Honored One, for the sake of the bodhisattvas, explained and distinguished the hearing of this samÄdhi, and the mind then aspires to the radiance of the Dharma.

'I have heard, God among Gods!

The Buddha PrabhÅ«taratna told Bodhisattva Aká¹£ayamati:

That bodhisattva, having heard from the World-Honored One, bowed at the Buddha's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, and then withdrew. He immediately went to a separate place to contemplate, and followed the practice in the transformed pavilion.

At that time, there was a Brahma Heaven named Good Light, who, together with seventy-two thousand Brahma Heavens, went to where the bodhisattva was, bowed at his feet, and as soon as he saw this, he asked the bodhisattva:

'At that time, when the son of a good family spoke, did the TathÄgata Guangming gather them, and did the bhiká¹£us who were sitting also speak the sÅ«tra, saying, One should practice two things: expounding the Dharma and the noble silence without thought.

Roughly answer the question.
The TathÄgata observes with his eyes and expounds the Dharma to the utmost.

At that time, seventy-two thousand BrahmÄ gods all gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, and the bodhisattva Subhadra attained the samÄdhi of universal illumination.

From hearing the TathÄgata's explanations, one is then silent.

In an instant, a bodhisattva can praise and explain the eloquence spoken for hundreds of thousands of eons. After practicing this, one should then give rise to this thought.

There was a bodhisattva named Majestic Savior of Exhausted Intentions who spoke these words in the human realm, which were the realm entered by Universal Practice Brahma Heaven and the two bodhisattvas.
Reflecting on the past, was it not someone else?
Do not view it in this way.

At that time, the bodhisattva Exhausted Intentions is now Universal;

Chapter 9: The Practice of Strength (3) Chapter 9: The Practice of Strength Thereupon, the Bodhisattva Universal Practice said to the Great Sage Buddha:

The World-Honored Ones of the TathÄgatas have lofty and wondrous virtue and conduct, and are able to attain such great benefits. They always diligently practice with effort, while those who are lazy, even if there are a hundred thousand Buddhas, cannot be helped.

The Youthful Head said to Universal Practice:

How can you distinguish and know what is followed and practiced, and is called diligent effort for a bodhisattva?

If a bodhisattva follows and practices, there is a time and no thought, and diligent effort is not abandoned.

If practitioners do not contemplate all dharmas, then at that time there is nothing to contemplate.
He further asked:

If one can practice all dharmas, and see them as equal, then at that time there is nothing to contemplate.

No, it is not.ğŸ”½

The Brahma Heaven Holder asked Pu Shou:

Pu Shou replied:

He replied:
Because of excluding the two things, there is no seeing. Not seeing anything is equal seeing.
He further asked:

He answered:

What I see is like form, without basis, not creating distinctions. As there is something seen, so there is feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, without basis, equal, and not distinguished.
If Puá¹£ya sees the five aggregates as without basis, then he manifests in the world, seeing equally.

To exhaust all characteristics is practice. This is the practice of Puá¹£ya in the world.
He further asked:
If the characteristics of the mind that extinguishes the world's characteristics are extinguished, how does one engage in the practice of extinguishing the characteristics of the mind?
He replied:
Puá¹£ya!
The characteristics of the world are not extinguished.
He further asked:

He replied:
That which is completely extinguished has nothing to extinguish, and that which is extinguished cannot be extinguished.
He further asked:
Brahma Heaven!
Didn't the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One say that the law of extinction refers to conditioned things?

Chapter 10: Aspiring to the Great Vehicle (3) Chapter 10: Aspiring to the Great Vehicle. At that time, Bodhisattva Universal Practice said to the World-Honored One:

Chapter 11: Practicing the Way (3) At that time, Samantabhadra addressed the World-Honored One, saying:

Why is it so?
God among Gods!

Moreover, seeing that the Way does not abide in the desire realm, does not abide in the form realm, and does not abide in the formless realm, the Way abides nowhere. For this reason, one should not aspire for it.

This is conditioned, this is unconditioned, this is worldly affairs, this is the practice of crossing the world?
